title: Cabinet member Kelly Loeffler gives hilarious tour of empty office to make point about controversial order
body:
Newly confirmed Small Business Administration (SBA) head Kelly Loeffler has shared a video tour of her agency's headquarters, highlighting vacant offices amid a push to end remote work for federal employees.

'It's my second day here at the SBA,' Loeffler said on Friday. 'I could not be more excited to be here. So I thought I'd take a walk.

'And what I found is that exactly what's been said is true. About 90 percent of our employees are working from home. Well, that ends Monday with President Trump's return to work,' she added.

The video has since amassed more than 21 million views on X.

Federal employees who have worked remotely, either fully or partially, for nearly five years must now return to the office following an executive order from Trump requiring all federal workers to resume in-person work.

Former Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior Department Jeremy Carl argued on X that the inability to fire federal employees leads to a lack of accountability.

'The problem with work from home in the federal government is that the employees cannot be fired,' he wrote. 'When you don't have to show up to the office, and there is no accountability for your performance [and] that is a recipe for disaster.'

Elon Musk, billionaire and head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), also weighed in, posting simply, 'No one at work.'

However, not everyone agreed with Loeffler's stance.

Newly confirmed Small Business Administration (SBA) head Kelly Loeffler shared a video tour of her agency's headquarters on Friday, highlighting vacant offices as she reinforced the administration's push to end remote work for federal employees

Federal employees who have worked remotely, either fully or partially, for nearly five years must now return to the office following an executive order from Trump requiring all federal workers to resume in-person work

Market researcher Anna Matson pushed back, defending remote work as beneficial for families.

'This is one of the worst Trump policies,' she wrote on Friday.

'There used to be one parent at home and one that worked. Now, both parents must work to survive.

'Adding 2-3 hours a day to their workday significantly reduces time with their family. If we want to support families, work from home when feasible should remain.'

Meanwhile, Congressional Republicans have called on Loeffler to provide answers regarding the SBA's failure to aggressively recover fraudulent or misallocated COVID relief funds.

Loeffler, 54, was the latest to be confirmed to lead the Small Business Administration on Wednesday, following Howard Lutnick who will lead the Commerce Department.

'A huge honor to be at the Capitol today as my former Senate colleagues voted to confirm me as the 28th Administrator of the U.S. Small Business Administration,' said Loeffler in a post on X.

'Profoundly grateful to @POTUS for the trust he's placed in me to help advance his America First agenda - and unleash a new era of growth, innovation, and prosperity for small business and all Americans.'

Loeffler, 54, was the latest to be confirmed to lead the Small Business Administration on Wednesday, following Howard Lutnick who will lead the Commerce Department

Loeffler previously co-chaired Trump's Inaugural Committee alongside Steve Witkoff, the former president's special envoy to the Middle East.

Before entering politics, she served as CEO of a financial services firm and later represented Georgia in Congress from 2020 to 2021.

Her husband, Jeffrey Sprecher, is the president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Kelly Loeffler.name: Kelly Loeffler

position_held.name: Administrator of the Small Business Administration

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Kelly Loeffler as the newly confirmed Small Business Administration head, confirming both her name and her role as a non‑elected government official.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article repeatedly refers to "Newly confirmed Small Business Administration (SBA) head Kelly Loeffler" and includes her title, age (54), and confirmation date. These details align precisely with the Wikidata entry for Kelly Loeffler, which lists her as Administrator of the Small Business Administration starting 2025‑02‑20, a businesswoman and politician, former U.S. senator, and former CEO. No other individual named Kelly Loeffler with a different occupation or affiliation appears in the text, so the identity match is unambiguous.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Kelly Loeffler is quoted directly in the article: "It's my second day here at the SBA," and later in a post on X. These are clear statements attributed to her. The article also reports her confirmation remarks and her comments on remote work policy, all directly linked to her.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the SBA Administrator to speak publicly about the agency’s headquarters, remote work policy, and her confirmation. The statements are consistent with her role and the policy context described.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article’s depiction of Kelly Loeffler and the Wikidata profile. The occupation, position, and biographical details all match.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Kelly Loeffler as the newly confirmed Small Business Administration head, confirming both her name and her role as a non‑elected government official.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Kelly Loeffler as the newly confirmed Small Business Administration head, confirming both her name and her role as a non‑elected government official.

reasoning.candidate_evaluation: None of the six provided Wikidata candidates have occupations, positions, or descriptions that align with a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior Department. All candidates are researchers or a non‑fiction writer, with no government or Interior Department affiliation. Therefore no candidate matches the entity described in the article.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity Jeremy Carl is present and making statements, but the supplied candidate list contains no suitable match for a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior Department. According to the guidelines, when the entity is present but no candidate fits, the correct output is "NONE".

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Elon Musk" and describes him as a billionaire. This matches the Wikidata entity’s name and general description (businessman/entrepreneur). Although the article incorrectly claims he is the head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), that statement does not alter the identity of the person being referenced; it is a false claim about his role, not a different individual. Therefore the Wikidata entity is present and identifiable in the article.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The article records that Elon Musk "also weighed in, posting simply, 'No one at work.'" This is a direct attribution of a statement to the entity.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: Given Elon Musk’s public presence on social media and his status as a billionaire entrepreneur, it is plausible that he would post a brief comment such as "No one at work." The statement is consistent with his known behavior of making terse, often humorous tweets.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: The article’s claim that Musk is head of DOGE is factually incorrect, but it does not contradict the identity of the person. It is a false attribution of a position, not a different individual.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly names Elon Musk and identifies him as a billionaire and head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), confirming both the name and the described role.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly names Elon Musk and identifies him as a billionaire and head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), confirming both the name and the described role.
